text.p: NOTE - Full name of the German business software company is SAP AG.
Management board chairman Dietmar Hopp noted that rate of sales growth slowed unexpectedly to 33 percent to the end of September after 38 percent at the end of June.
"The rather moderate growth in the third quarter was unexpected and attributable to a few countries," he said in a statement.
"Nevertheless we continue to see very strong demand for R/3," he added.
Revenues in the first nine months of 1996, while highest in the group's history, were below both the company's and market's expectations.
Independent analysts had been expecting sales growth of around 40 percent.
"We have recognised the causes of this surprising weakness in growth and have implemented corresponding steps," Hopp added.
"The moderate growth in the third quarter means that the previous sales target is no longer achievable. We now expect 1996 revenues to be 3.5 billion marks."
Hopp said SAP had expended much of its efforts recently on development and that it would now refocus on sales.
Paul Wahl, chief executive for SAP in North America, said the company had added 70 new employees to its sales force.

"The market opportunities for SAP in North America remain strong and as we continue our expansion into the mid-market and new vertical industries we will continue to realise significant growth," Wahl said in the statement.
SAP's group workforce increased by 1,614 employees to 8,471 at the end of September. Of the total increase, 1,144 new staff were added outside Germany.
